head.title: Not So Fast on the Ozone Layer Celebration; Aerosol Changeover

hedline.hl1: Not So Fast on the Ozone Layer Celebration; Aerosol Changeover

block.p: Information that the buildup of chlorofluorocarbons in the atmosphere is leveling off is truly good news -- so was your Aug. 26 front-page article's note that this is a case where science, government, industry and the public worked together.

Information that the buildup of chlorofluorocarbons in the atmosphere is leveling off is truly good news -- so was your Aug. 26 front-page article's note that this is a case where science, government, industry and the public worked together.

The American aerosol industry began the phaseout of chlorofluorocarbon propellants in its products in the 1970's. By the time the Environmental Protection Agency and Food and Drug Administration banned chlorofluorocarbons from spray cans in 1978, the great majority of products were using alternative propellants.

In aerosols, the global changeover from chlorofluorocarbons is almost complete. The industry's best estimates are that less than 10 percent of the chlorofluorocarbons produced worldwide last year were used in spray cans, and that figure is dropping rapidly.

Most Americans are unaware of the actions taken by their Government and the aerosol industry. Repeated surveys, including one last year by Opinion Research Corporation, show that the majority of consumers don't know about the aerosol changeover and believe aerosols represent a significant threat to the ozone layer.

The industry has worked hard to change this misperception. We are glad you mentioned the real aerosol can situation. CAROL LIPPINCOTT Washington, Sept. 1, 1993 The writer is with the Consumer Aerosol Products Council.
